direction.raw_text: . The sun, spinning up from behind the dark rim of eastern hills, is bleaching the cloudless, morning sky. This is volcanic country, barren, desolate, forbidding. There is no sign of life, no sound. Then on a distant hill, a man appears, to be followed by two others. They walk steadily forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NARROW CANYON - DAWN MED. SHOT. A dry watercourse threads its way through the cut in the treeless hills. The sun is not high enough as yet to drive night from the canyon. A man appears around a bend; another and still another. They are McCall, Peters and Lednov, clad in prison clothes, hatless, their heads closely cropped. As Lednov's face comes into a closeup, DISSOLVE EXT. HILL - DAWN LONG SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. A narrow valley lies below. Through it runs a cottonwood-bordered stream. Smoke curls up out of the trees. Horses graze in a small meadow near the creek. From O.O. comes the SOUND of heavy boots crunching across the dry, eroded earth. The three men file past camera to stop in the immediate F.g. and look down into the valley. They exchange glances and start down. DISSOLVE EXT. FORSTER CAMP - DAWN MED. SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH willows. A bearded man, Cal Forster, and two young fellows in their late teens squat beside a campfire eating breakfast. O.s. there is the SOUND of movement. Lednov moves cautiously into the scene. He has a revolver in his hand. Forster turns toward camera and fear comes into his expression. Lednov fires. Forster crumples near the fire. The two boys jump to their feet and reach for rifles. Lednov fires again and again. McCall and Peters come into the scene, both firing revolvers. DISSOLVE EXT. FORSTER CAMP - DAWN MED SHOT - ANGLED ACROSS campfire. On the fire smoulders the prison clothes the convicts had worn. Smoke spirals up. In the B.B. Lednov, Peters and McCall, now wearing the clothes of the three Forsters, saddle the horses. CAMERA PANS AROUND and ANGLES DOWN. The bodies of Forster and his sons, now clad in underwear are sprawled by the fire. Forster's arm lies close to the smouldering clothing. DISSOLVE EXT. CREEK - DAWN MED. LONG SHOT. Smoke climbs above the trees. Into the clearing ride the three convicts, to cross it and move westward. They disappear over the hill. A dust cloud marks their passage. CAMERA HOLDS ON the scene and over the shot comes the MAIN TITLE CARD:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DESERT ROAD - DAY LONG SHOT. A buckboard drawn by two horses comes along the road. Graham, a middle-aged rancher, is driving. As the horses trot forward and dust rises above the road, the NEXT TITLE CARD is shown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CREEK - DAY LONG SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. Graham's buckboard moves down the road toward the clearing, as the TITLE CARDS follow and change. When the buckboard reaches the creek, the LAST TITLE CARD is ended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Graham drives the horses through the creek and into the meadow. Through the trees the Forster camp can be seen. Graham glances over, then suddenly pulls on the reins. As the horses stop, he twists the reins around the whip stock, grabs his rifle from under the seat, leaps out and hurries forward toward the camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Graham hurries through the trees to stop in horror near the dead men. Then very slowly he moves forward to the smouldering fire. Stooping he lifts Forster's arm away from the fire, then picks up one of the prison coats and looks at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DESERT ROAD - DAY MED. LONG SHOT. The surrounding hills are covered with scrub pinon pine and mesquite. Graham's buckboard, moving slowly up a hill, passes camera, which PANS WITH it. In the bed, covered by a tarp, are the three bodies. The narrow, one-way road climbs easily up the gentle hill. Beyond, a dust cloud rises. As Graham's buckboard nears the crest, a surrey appears and starts down. Graham pulls his team into the bank, trying to make room for the surrey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are four women in the two-seated surrey, which is heavily loaded with trunks, hatboxes, etc. Mary Wells, the loveliest of the four, is driving. She is more poised, more self-assured than the others. Her clothes, though a trifle showy, are attractive. She wears a large spectacular hat. Helen Carter, showier, harder and more cynical, sits beside her. In the seat behind are Marcia Paine, placid, younger looking than her years, and Elaine Ross, a striking blonde with a pale haunted face. Elaine is obviously ill. Mary is riding the brake and holding the team back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING PAST Graham.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jerks on the reins and tries to make room for the surrey. A steep bank is on camera left. On camera right, the road drops off into a gulley. As the surrey comes up Mary reins the team in. The women all look frightened. Graham, trying to force his team to pull the vehicle up the bank, is too occupied to recognize the women at once. Having made just enough room for the surrey, he turns and looks at the women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary looks ahead at the narrow road and the canyon to her left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Graham jumps over the wheel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed) What in thunderation -- (calling) Wait a minute -- stop --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- (then surprised) What are you girls doin' way out here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Until you came along we were going to Sonora.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you know about that. Did you sell your place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Not exactly. They decided gambling and dancing were bad for people. (pointing) Can I make it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Depends on how good you drive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a little out of practice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE ON SURREY Graham reaches the surrey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She climbs out. Marcia looks at the narrow space ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine leans back against the cushions and shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen is out on the road now. Mary has moved over and Graham picks up the reins. Marcia gives up and jumps out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He releases the brake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary isn't listening. She is looking at the road. Elaine closes her eyes. Helen and Marcia scurry back out of the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adroitly he drives the surrey past.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cheerfully) Slide over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up) I'm slidin' all the way over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) So am I. Come on Elaine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flat) What's the difference if we fall in the canyon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't talk like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothin' to it --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: once you know how. Trouble is, never was a woman knew how to handle a team. Shouldn't let 'em loose on the roads. No disrespect meant, Miss Wells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: featuring buckboard. Helen and Marcia start along the road past the buckboard. Helen stops and looks at its cargo in horror. She grabs Marcia's arm. The girls look at each other and hurry after the surrey which has stopped below the buckboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on surrey. Graham jumps out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen and Marcia hurry up. Marcia motions back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The women exchange glances. Elaine is sitting up, her eyes open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Mary speaks, Helen pushes Marcia into the surrey and climbs up beside Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary unwraps the reins from the whipstock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary releases the brake and the surrey starts rolling forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The surrey starts down the hill. Graham looks after it, then turns to go back to the buckboard, CAMERA PANNING WITH him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ASPEN - DAY - (MATTE SHOT) The town lies in a lush green valley. It is surrounded by meadowland and shaded by cottonwoods, alders and aspen. In the F.g. Graham's buckboard moves fast down hill. DISSOLVE OUT EXT. ASPEN STREET - DAY DISSOLVE IN FULL SHOT. In the F.g. a smallish crowd, mostly men and children idle in the street in front of Mary Wells' Gambling and Dance Hall. The wooden sidewalk is cluttered with those articles belonging to the women that were too bulky to get into the surrey. Several women stand on the porch supervising the locking up of the place and the removal of the sign of Mary Wells' name on it. Graham's buckboard rounds a corner at a fast trot. He slows the team to let the people get out of the way.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There you are. Now take it easy and you'll be all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Mr. Graham.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (aghast) There's -- dead men -- in your wagon!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right. You had me so busy I forgot -- (worried) Come to think of it you better turn around and drive right back to Aspen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were murdered. I found the bodies on Alder Crick, northeast of here. Like I said if I was you, I'd go back, because the men who killed them might be on this road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) Back to what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, back to Aspen, where you came from.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aspen doesn't want us Mr. Graham. They threw us out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distressed) They shouldn't have done that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We tried to point that out. But there were some pretty nosey citizens who wouldn't listen to reason. They said Aspen had outgrown us. It's all right to play poker in your own home but not in a saloon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sadly) I knew something would happen when they started puttin' up fences and passin' laws.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye and thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't like to see you go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that's the way it is. The live ones go out and the dead ones come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The team has slowed to a walk. The people give their attention to the buckboard. A boy clambers up over the tailboard, sees the cargo and jumps off with a frightened yell. The crowd turns from the dance hall and follows the buckboard leaving the women and their pious male assistants on the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT - ANGLED to include blacksmith shop across the street. Far down the street comes Graham's buckboard followed by the small crowd. The sheriff's office is a one- story wooden structure. Next to it is the general store. In front of the blacksmith shop stands a wagon with one wheel off. In the corral alongside are eleven blooded mares. Clay Phillips, his brother Steve and the blacksmith are inside the shop. Clay's saddle horse is tethered to the hitching rail beside two harnessed work horses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D to include sheriff's office. The blacksmith, Sam Ellis, an elderly bent man in a leather apron stands at the forge in which he is heating the rim from the big wheel which lies on the table nearby. Clay, a long-legged wrangler in clean but faded work clothes stands near the forge pumping the bellows and watching his brother, a freckled kid of sixteen trying to roll a cigarette. Steve has progressed to the most difficult step, that of licking and sealing the paper. Clay reaches over and takes it from him. He puts the skinny cylinder in his mouth and Steve lights it for him. The first third of the cigarette burns with one quick flare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sam lifts the rim to the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay, the cigarette dangling from his lips, moves over to the table, picks up a hammer and helps Sam hammer the rim on the wheel. Steve stands watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Together they lift the wheel and plunge it into the tub of water. Steam rises to fill the blackened shed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay and Sam spin the wheel in the tub.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From O.s. comes the SOUND of the approaching buckboard and crowd. Steve hears the noise and moves to the front of the shed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How does she draw?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little hot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to get out of here before noon, maybe you should lend me a hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rate you're goin', we'll be here until winter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amiably grumbling) Account of you, I miss out on the only excitement Aspen's had for months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're too old to watch such goin's on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I'm too young.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't see no sense to makin' people leave town if they don't want to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't either -- when people are that good-lookin'. Maybe that's why -- they were too good-lookin'. (philosophically) But there'll be others along to take their place after a while when this quiets down. And everything will be fine until some busybody starts stirring up trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly) Don't you ever run down?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Steve) Some people just have to run other people's lives. Now take Clay. You want to amble up the street and see the fun and what does he say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (good-natured) You stick to your blacksmithin' and let me take care of Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT - Steve's angle. Graham pulls his buckboard up, jumps out and hurries into the sheriff's office. Some kids run up to stand on the porch chattering excitedly. Members of the crowd straggle up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D PAST Steve. Clay comes up to stand beside Steve. Sam joins them. Steve looks up at Clay hopefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay and Steve exit. Sam looks after them, shrugs disgustedly and goes back to the wheel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We'll both take a look. Anything's better than listenin' to Sam. (to Sam) Don't forget to shoe the mule.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - featuring buckboard. The crowd around the wagon stands in shocked silence looking at the bodies under the tarp. Clay and steve come up, glance in the buckboard and then at each other. Clay speaks to a man near him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sheriff calls from O.s.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who are they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't know. Graham brought 'em in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay, come up here a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: FEATURING PORCH Sheriff Gardner, who has seen Clay through the window, comes out of his office on to the porch followed by Jeb Graham and a young deputy. In his hand Gardner holds the burned prison jacket. Clay goes up the steps to the porch. Steve follows to the foot of the steps to stand watching. The crowd around the wagon gives its attention to the men on the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gardner is neatly dressed with his star hidden under his coat. His deputy wears jeans, shirt, and leather jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses to let that sink in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gardner holds out the burned jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay moves over to glance down at the jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From his pocket, Gardner takes several communications, thumbs through them and passes one over. It is a telegram, of the period.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay reads it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello Graham -- Joe -- Mr. Gardner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Graham's got something to tell you might interest you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (motioning toward wagon) Cal Forster and his sons. Somebody killed 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know that cottonwood grove on Alder Crick? They must have been eatin' breakfast the way it looked, sittin' by the fire eatin' breakfast and when I got there nothin' but them lyin' dead in their underdrawers. No horses or guns or grub.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shocked) Forster never did anyone any harm. (puzzled) But what's that got to do with me? I came into town from the south.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This was smoulderin' on the fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I still don't see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got it day before yesterday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: TELEGRAM OF THE PERIOD:
direction.name: direction

result.heading: BE ADVISED OF ESCAPE OF LEDNOV, PETERS AND
GROVE, WARDEN STATE PENITENTIARY NORTON, NEV

direction.raw_text: : ASPEN, NEV. BE ADVISED OF ESCAPE OF LEDNOV, PETERS AND McCALL CONVICTED MURDERERS SERVING LIFE TERMS. BELIEVED HEADED FOR CALIFORNIA. L.B. GROVE, WARDEN STATE PENITENTIARY NORTON, NEV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Clay hands the telegram back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns toward the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay speaks over his shoulder as he goes down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now are you interested?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should be. Maybe Lednov heard about that Sonora ranch of yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe he did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going to look for him. Want to come along?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got eleven horses to get over the mountains before snow catches me and covers the feed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) And that's more important than finding Lednov?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like you said, maybe he knows where my ranch is. If he does, he'll be waiting on the porch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with irony) I'll drop the sheriff in Sonora a line to sort of look around for him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Clay starts away, Steve follows him. Clay doesn't cross to the blacksmith shop. He goes along the sidewalk toward the general store. Steve hurries to catch up with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Clay, deep in thought, seems unaware of his brother at his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk in silence to the General store and Clay goes up the steps and across the porch. Steve follows close behind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's Lednov?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man I used to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The store is a typical general store of the period, selling everything from buggies to baby clothes. In one corner is the postoffice. The storekeeper, Hayes, is unpacking a case of canned goods, stacking the cans on the shelf. Clay, followed by Steve, enters. Hayes glances over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay crosses to the shelf where the rifle and shotgun shells are kept and takes down a half dozen boxes of 30 30 cartridges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Besides Clay, Steve is inspecting a rack of guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve picks up a rifle, puts it to his shoulder and squints along the barrel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls the hammer back and snaps the trigger. Hayes comes across and takes the gun from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands Hayes some money for the shells. Hayes crosses to another part of the store to get change. Clay and Steve, who has picked up the rifle again, move over to the counter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Forget somethin', Clay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shells. How much for six boxes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Six times six bits. But wait until I finish this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You might tell a fellow things, 'specially if the fellow's your brother, seems to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like why you're buyin' a whole slew of 30 30 shells all of a sudden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to run short.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You never said this Lednov's name before, that I can remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No call to. That jail looked pretty solid to me. (pointing to rifle) How's she feel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know bettern' to do that, Steve. Unless you're figurin' on buyin' it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One he's got, more his size.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's leaded up and anyway a 22's no good for real huntin'. You shoot a man with a 22 and where are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The thing to do is stick to rabbits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: STEVE What was he in jail for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay grins. Hayes comes up with the change. Clay takes out some bills and gives them to the storekeeper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve's expression shows his gratitude and delight. He covers up with banter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts one of the boxes of shells on the end of the counter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You sure worry that bone. He killed a fellow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a fight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The other fellow wasn't even lookin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is an awful nice gun. (sighting it) Certainly come in handy when there's men around who shoot people that aren't lookin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (points to rifle) I may as well buy it for him. Otherwise he'll be crying all the way over the hill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be plenty worried about Lednov sneakin' up on us. (hopefully) Think he will?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At the ranch maybe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe at the ranch. Maybe sooner than that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed) Do you have to be so close-mouthed? I'm your brother. And I'm ridin' with you. Remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) All right. I'll tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE - DOWN ANGLE CLAY Let's say this is the penitentiary. He reaches down into one of the barrels in front of the counter. The barrels are filled with beans, nails, dried apples, hardtack, etc. Clay takes a handful of beans and makes a trail ending in a little pile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts another box of shells on the other side of the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs a trail of beans away from "Aspen" toward the end of the counter. He runs another trail from "Alder Crick" to cross the Aspen trail. He puts another box of shells on the far end of the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches down without looking and brings up a hardtack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay drops the hardtack back from where the bean trails cross.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds out his hand and Hayes hands him his change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve tucks his gun under his arm. As he passes the counter, he picks up the hardtack and starts eating it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here's Alder Crick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And here we are in Aspen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's Sonora.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: motioning) Lednov gets out of jail and comes along here to Alder Crick. Then goes along here toward the Sonora road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's Lednov! (tracing) We come along here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing) And meet him there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unless the sheriff gets too close and he holes up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GENERAL STORE MED. SHOT - ANGLED TOWARD Sheriff's office. Up the street men are gathering around the sheriff's office. Some are mounted. Some are tightening their cinches. Clay and Steve come out of the store to look up the street. Steve munches the hardtack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He glances at the remaining piece of hardtack and then pitches it away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay laughs. As they start up the street, the sheriff mounts his horse and, followed by his men, rides forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DESERT ROAD - DAY CLOSE SHOT. A woman's hat lies on the rocky earth. It is a big, elaborate affair. O.s. there is the SOUND of hoofbeats, the SQUEAL of a wagon brake and the JANGLE of harness. CAMERA PULLS BACK and ANGLE WIDENS to reveal Clay's wagon coming down a very steep hill. Steve is driving, holding tightly to the reins and riding the brake. Seeing the hat, he yells to Clay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay rides over and, swinging down, picks it up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (motioning) Sure a lot of guys lookin' for Lednov.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah -- and Lednov's only lookin' for one man. Me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He doesn't like me. What you eatin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lednov.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't like him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another one, Clay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ANGLED DOWN hill. The road twists tortuously down. Near the bottom it swings sharply at right angles into a dry wash. The banks shut out further view of the road. Near where the road turns a trunk lies at the side. It has broken open and some of the contents are spilled out in the dust. Clay rides to it, reins in his horse and looks down. Steve, with difficulty, pulls the mules to a stop alongside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: featuring trunk and wagon. Clay swings out of his saddle, starts tossing the clothes back in the trunk. Steve jumps down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve holds up a petticoat close to his body and grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay takes it from him, puts it in the trunk and shuts the lid. Steve helps him hoist the trunk into the wagon bed. Steve gets back in the seat. Just as Clay is about to mount, he stops and picks up a small folding daguerrotype case delicately ornamented. He lifts his eyebrow, tucks the case into his pocket, then mounts and starts ahead around the bend.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They sure must have been travelin'. This keeps up we can start a store.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Things get tough next winter, you'll have somethin' to wear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd look good doin' the ploughin' in this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT Clay's ANGLE. Ahead, off the road in the wash is the surrey that passed Graham's buckboard at the fork. Clay spurs his horse forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on surrey. The back wheel is broken and the bed of the surrey rests on the ground. The horses have been taken from the traces and stand dejectedly in the hot sun. A blanket is spread in the scant shade thrown by the surrey. On it lies Elaine and, sitting beside her, is Marcia. A damp cloth is spread across Elaine's forehead. A water bag hangs from the surrey. Elaine's head is pillowed on a dainty satin cushion. Helen and Mary have risen at Clay's approach and now stand by the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay gallops forward to pull up near the surrey. In the b.g. Steve drives the wagon around the bend. Clay dismounts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GROUP SHOT Clay drops his reins and hurries up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay bends over Elaine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay turns from Elaine and gives his attention to the surrey.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Anybody hurt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. We came down the hill a little fast and... (rueful) ...the wheel broke. (hopefully) Can you fix it for us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Too much excitement. How about the surrey. Can you fix it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on rear of surrey. In the B.g. Steve pulls the wagon to a stop, jumps off, and comes running over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen moves toward Clay. She miles without humor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay stops her with a look, goes around, and kicks the unbroken back wheel. The spokes rattle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him to see if the name registers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve tugs at his battered hat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary and Helen exchange glances.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay takes the makings from his pocket, starts to roll a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve looks at Clay hopefully. He likes the prospect of having these lovely women along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay finishes the cigarette, starts to put the makings back. Mary holds out her hand. Clay gives her the makings. Mary speaks as she casually rolls a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay motions to the remuda that grazes in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary has finished rolling her cigarette. She passes the bag to Helen, who starts rolling one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen has finished her cigarette. She passes the makings to Steve. He hesitates, looks at his brother and, when he sees Clay is occupied with Mary, starts rolling one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve finishes his cigarette. Again he hesitates, then not wanting to seem young in front of these women he takes a bold step and lights it. Clay reaches over and takes it from him. Mary watches the byplay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve, embarrassed and hurt, turns quickly away. Helen looks after the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He lifts some things out of the surrey and carries them toward the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts around the surrey. Helen follows. Clay bends over Elaine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Clay turns from Elaine, Marcia joins the other two, their attention on Clay and the surrey. Left alone, Elaine is suddenly alert and no longer sick. She glances around, then unobserved slides out from under the shade of the surrey.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jimininy. You sure were lucky, just bustin' a wheel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rubbing thigh) You think that'sall we busted -- You should see...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This must have been in the family a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) It was a gift from the citizens of Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And this is Helen Carter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Clay Phillips. (motioning) My brother Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shy) Pleased to meet you, ma'am. (brightly) We found your trunk. Were you doin' the driven'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was at first. Then I was hanging on. (to Clay) Are you going far?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As far as -- Sonora?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going to Sonora, too, so that solves everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can ride in your wagon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We wouldn't think of asking you to take us for nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's only four of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got eleven horses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (proudly) Morgan blood. The beat in Nevada. Clay and me have a place on the Toulomne River. We're going to raise horses like these.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They won't be riding in the wagon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Did you ever try taking a bunch of horses over Sonora Pass? It's quite a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't leave us here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Course I can't. I'll give you a lift to the first ranch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What good is it going to do us to go to some ranch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (amiably) You can stay here if you like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to get to Sonora. There are jobs waiting for us there. We'll pay you for your trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not running a stage line, ma'am, and I can't take a chance on losing the horses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you're old enough to smoke, I'll tell you. (kind) Get the horses started on ahead, will you, Steve?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Afraid it will stop him growin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning) Let's get your stuff in the wagon. Like I said, I'll take you to the first ranch. I wish I could carry you all the way, but I can't. It's a tough trip and women would be in the way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Our kind of women?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ignores that) You'll have to drive -- except down hill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you're going about this all wrong. Why not try telling him we'll do the cookin' and mendin' and washin' for him. That usually works. (then shocked at the thought) Yeah, but suppose he took us up on it. Where would we be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe in Sonora.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Too much excitement. Or maybe it's just the heat. How about the surrey. Can you fix it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on rear of surrey. In the B.g. Steve pulls the wagon to a stop, jumps off, and comes running over. Elaine stands for a moment, searching the ground with her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen moves toward Clay. She smiles without humor. With this new diversion, Elaine, still unnoticed, starts away -- back toward where they dropped the trunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine stops now and turns as Clay takes the folding daguerrotype case from his pocket. Elaine, her eyes wide and frightened, starts back as Mary takes the case from Clay and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She jerks the case from Mary's hands, snaps it shut, and stands staring at Mary with a strange mixture of fright, anger and hysteria. Mary glances around as if to say what- did-I-do? To cover the embarrassed silence, Clay kicks the unbroken back wheel. The spokes rattle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine glances at him as though he had insulted her, turns and starts toward the blanket again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him to see if the name registers. At the surrey side, Elaine is abruptly weak again. She leans against it for support. Mareia moves to her as she slides back down on the blanket, clutching the case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve tugs at his battered hat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jiminy. You sure were lucky, just bustin' a wheel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rubbing thigh) You think that's all we busted -- You should see...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sees Elaine) Now where's she goin'? -- ELAINE (half-turns without stopping)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: lost something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It wouldn't happen to be this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's the old folks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frantic) Give it to me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This must have been in the family a long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) It was a gift from the citizens of Aspen. I'm Mary Wells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And this is Helen Carter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Clay Phillips. (motioning) My brother Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shy) Pleased to meet you, ma'am. (brightly) We found your trunk. Were you doin' the drivin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mary and Helen come around the end of the surrey to where Elaine lies. Mary bends beside the sick girl and lifts the cloth from the girl's forehead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sick girl sits up. She looks around her dully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Assisted by Mary, Elaine gets to her feet. Mary puts her arm around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine stops. She looks fearfully up at Helen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She tries to lead the girl toward the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pulls the girl with her toward the wagon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Honeybunch. We're changing trains.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A nice, kind wrangler is letting us ride in his wagon...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...as far as the first ranch. From then on --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What ranch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the difference?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fierce) Ask him what ranch -- MARY There's plenty of time for that. (sharp) Come on, now. You've got to lie down out of this sun. Stop worrying. I'll find out what ranch after a while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on wagon. Clay, in the wagon bed, is stowing his gear in the back. Mary, supporting Elaine, reaches the wagon. Seeing the girls, Clay reaches down and gently lifts Elaine up. Mary climbs in beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE wagon bed. Clay has unrolled a bedroll under the seat where there is a little shade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she speaks, Mary helps the girl down under the seat, then rises to face Clay.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (kind) Stretch out under the seat, Miss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (desperate) Which ranch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's worried about where you're taking us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) So am I.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a nice place owned by an old couple named Wyatt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Elaine as she hears the name. She is shocked.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They'll take you in until you can make other arrangements.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay and Mary. Clay vaults out of the wagon, CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS, he looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away and hurries back to the surrey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DESERT ROAD - DAY FULL SHOT. Dust rises over the road as the cavalcade moves forward. Clay, rifle across his lap, rides in front. The wagon, with Mary driving and Helen beside her on the seat, follows. The two horses that pulled the surrey are tied to the tail gate. Then comes the remuda with Steve bringing up the rear.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So both of you stop worrying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marcia and Elaine. PROCESS. Marcia sits in the bed of the wagon looking back. Elaine lies under the seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve. Steve proudly carries his new rifle across his lap. He whistles happily as he scans the desert country hopefully for the enemy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Long shadows of the hills lie on the grassy meadow along the stream that is bordered by cottonwoods and willows. A knoll overlooks the camp site. The caravan can be seen as it halts in the lush grass a few yards from the stream. The girls sit lifelessly on the wagon; they seem too tired to dismount. Then, finally, Marcia helps Elaine to climb stiffly down. With the exception of Mary they all let themselves down in the grass. Mary walks to the head of the team and starts fumbling with the harness. Steve comes into the scene, dismounts quickly and pulls the saddle off his horse. The remuda has fanned out, the horses moving toward the water. Steve crosses to Mary and takes over the job of unbuckling the harness. Mary smiles gratefully and rubs her hand across her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve straightens, looks towards the horses and moves off. He speaks to Mary over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary smiles after him, then moves across the grass, CAMERA DOLLYING AHEAD of her. She sinks to her knees in the patch of sand by the stream and leans down and puts her face under the water. Then, sitting up, she wipes the water and dust from her face with a handkerchief. Clay rides up from behind, dismounts, scoops up some water from the river in the brim of his hat and drinks it. For a second he watches Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary's manner is business-like. She and the girls are along for the ride. She wants no favors -- wants to do her part.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and leads his horse back to the wagon, stands there unsaddling it. Mary rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts downstream.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Steve, see the horses don't drink too much --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave that unharnessing for me, Ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a place down a ways, where you and the girls can wash some of that dust off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks. And isn't there something we can do about supper -- or making the beds?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (half-smile) Steve and me, we use a saddle for a pillow and roll up in a tarp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (curt) But you eat, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mostly, we open a can of beans and boil some coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you keep the can opener?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the grub box. (softening) Toward morning the dew gets kind of heavy so maybe you better fix up a bed under the wagon. Spread some bunch grass under the tarp and the ground won't be so hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Marcia -- all of you. Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ANGLED PAST wagon. Clay tosses the saddle into the wagon bed, slaps his mare on the rump. She trots off. Climbing up on the wheel, he gets the grub box under the seat and lifts it down. Steve comes from out of scene and starts unharnessing the team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay comes past him, carrying the grub box. He puts it down near where some stones make a crude firebox.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay squats by the stones and starts building a fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fans the small flame with his hat. Steve leads the mules down toward the stream.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (trying to be casual) Where'd they go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Swimming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's sort of nice having company along. Not so lonesome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you get the team watered, rustle up some wood.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ANGLED PAST Clay. In the B.g. Steve stands by the stream, letting the team drink. O.s. the women can be heard laughing and splashing. Steve gives all his attention to what is going on downstream. Clay puts wood on the fire, opens the grub box. He sees Steve, takes the coffee pot out of the box and heads for the stream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT ANGLED PAST Steve downstream. Behind the willows the girls are bathing. However they are too far away to be seen clearly and the willows make a fairly effective screen. Clay walks upstream and fills the coffee pot, then comes back to stand for a moment beside Steve. Steve, who hadn't seen Clay until now, suddenly gets very busy giving all his attention to the mules.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He jerks them from the water and leads them away. Clay frowns after him, then goes back to the wagon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to mules) You boys have had enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on wagon and fire. As Clay passes the wagon, he reaches into the bed and gets a couple of strips of scrap iron. These he carries to the fire. He puts the iron strips across the blaze, sets the coffee pot on, feeds the fire with some more wood, then going back to the wagon, he takes his rifle out, throws a shell into the chamber and starts off up the knoll.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KNOLL - NIGHT MED. SHOT. It is a moonlight night. Clay squats on his heels, smoking. The rifle lies across his knees. Below can be seen the campfire, and the shadowy forms of the girls as with Steve's help they make up a bed under the wagon and cook the evening meal. Clay suddenly reacts as O.s. a horse whinnies. Standing he looks off into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANGLED PAST Clay. In the moonlight the trail stretches back over rolling hills. Faintly can be heard the SOUND of hoofbeats. Below, where the remuda grazes, a horse whinnies again. Clay moves down toward the camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the camp. As Clay approaches. Steve squats by the fire. He has spread out a tarp in the circle of firelight and Mary is setting the tin plates, cups, etc., out. Elaine, a blanket around her, sits near the fire. She looks tired and ill. Marcia and Helen are struggling with bed-making under the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve and Mary look up as Clay strides up. Clay starts kicking dirt over the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve jumps up and hurries to the wagon. Clay continues kicking dirt over the fire.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And I'm the girl who used to complain to my mother about helping with the wash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get your rifle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - (MOONLIGHT)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: horseman. The horseman, who has been approaching from the east, tops a rise and looks off at the camp. He is a shadowy figure in the palo dark. For a moment, as the fire still blazes, figures are visible in the camp. Then the fire goes out. The horseman dismounts, pulling his rifle from his scabbard. Moving to his horse's head he puts a hand on the animal's nostrils. He looks toward the camp for a moment then starts cautiously along the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - (MOONLIGHT)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: willows PAST Clay and Steve. The brothers have taken up a post overlooking the road. The horseman walks cautiously toward them. He stops, listening. Then he drops his reins and comes forward stealthily. The horse stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT Clay and Steve. Steve, finger on trigger gives Clay a questioning glance. Clay shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Hold it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on road. The man, now seen clearly for the first time, stops. He is Jim Clayton, a man in his twenties, chunky, round-faced, stolid and not too imaginative. He wears the well-worn jeans and blue shirt of the farmer. Clay and Steve come out of the willows toward him. Both have their rifles ready.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clayton hesitates, then lets his rifle butt drop to the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay and Steve lower their rifles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay moves closer and extends his hand. They shake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve shakes Jim's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clayton turns back toward his horse. Clay and Steve wait for him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Drop your gun.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly) Drop yours. I'm gunshy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then don't come sneakin' around a man's camp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A fellow sees a fire go out all of a sudden, he don't take chances. My name's Clayton and I'm looking for someone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I found their surrey -- CLAY So did I. They were in it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's a friend -- took off this morning sort of sudden while I wasn't around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very cordial) I'm glad you came along. (introducing) My brother, Steve. I'm Phillips.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I gave the girls a lift. Didn't know what else to do with them. Get your horse and come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - (MOONLIGHT)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the trail. Mary and Helen, tense and worried, stand at the edge of the camp, looking off. Marcia is with Elaine under the wagon. From o.s. comes the SOUND of men's voices. Clay, Steve and Clayton, leading his horse, come into view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marcia kneeling on the tarp by Elaine, is staring ahead. Suddenly her face lights up. She springs to her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay, Steve and Jim are now close to Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hearing his voice, Marcia runs toward them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (genial) Here's a man says he's looking for you girls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Miss Wells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Marcia throws herself into Jim's arms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Clayton kisses her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marcia hugs him. In the B.g. Clay goes over to the fire, kicks the dirt off the embers and piles on wood. The fire flares up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was roundin' up some stock. That's why I didn't come sooner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean running off without a word.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mary and Helen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't know who to tell, it all happened so sudden, those people comin' and throwin' us out on the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you think about it, darlin'. Don't you think about anythin' but us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) Looks like we lose a good piano player.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WIDENS as Marcia and Jim come forward. The fire now burns briskly. Clay rejoins the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary speaks before Jim can answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The joy goes out of Marcia's expression. She looks up at Jim, her eyes begging him to tell her it will work. Jim, a naturally shy man, loses his tongue momentarily. Clay jumps into the breach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary turns on Clay.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (happily) Jim came after me, Mary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) I see he did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With a milk pail in one hand and a marriage license in the other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharp) Why didn't you say you wanted to get married back in Aspen. I told the man in Sonora there were four of us. If only three show up, he might call the whole deal off. We've got to stick together. Like we've always done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a chance to get married.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) That's what I'm gettin' at. It never works. Don't forget we were thrown out of Aspen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jim doesn't care, do you, Jim?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But Jim isn't the only one you're marrying. He has folks and friends. What are they going to say? And how're they going to feel? I tell you, it won't work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course it'll work. You can get another girl to fill out the act.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring him) And look at it this way. How about Jim -- it puts him in a sort of tough spot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what I'm doing. My folks got nothin' to do with it -- MARY You've talked this over with them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They know about Marcia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quickly) And they don't like the idea!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suppose they don't. This is his problem. He's over twenty-one. He wants to marry Marcia and Marcia wants to marry him so let 'em alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay and Mary. The others in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If you were in his shoes would you take one of us home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not in his shoes, so leave me out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (friendly) I would!

dialogue.raw_text: (hurriedly; smiles) Steve maybe you better get some wood for the fire.

dialogue.raw_text: (to Steve) Go on, there's a good boy.

dialogue.raw_text: (bitter) Don't you want him to hear your answer? Well, I know what it is. For the other fellow it's all right -- but not you. All you want is to get rid of one of us.

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No need of you two arguin' about this. We know what we want to do, and nothin' either of you says makes any difference. We want to go home -- tonight. (to Clay) Will you sell me one of your horses?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry. I can't do that. I went a long way to get those horses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, we'll ride double. Come on, Marcia.

direction.raw_text: featuring Marcia and Jim. In the B.g. Mary comes after them.

direction.raw_text: Jim and Marcia turn.

direction.raw_text: Marcia comes over to hug Mary. As Marcia and Jim leave, Mary moves to Clay.

direction.raw_text: . CAMP SITE - NIGHT MED. SHOT. Mary stands in the moonlight by the wagon, looking out across the meadow. Below, near the creek, the horses graze. There is the soft jangle of a bell as the bell mare moves her head. Clay comes walking up from the creek, rifle in hand. He passes without noticing Mary. Mary turns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No need to do that, Marcia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got two horses and they're four of us. So half of one of 'em is yours. (smiling) The other half's a wedding present.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Big-hearted fella. Can't see young love thwarted -- especially if it makes one less girl to worry about. That's all you really want, isn't it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mary in close F.g. The campfire burns low. Steve lies on his stomach close to it. Clay stops beside him to glance down, then moves on to sit on a rock above the fire. Mary starts toward the fire.

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Steve. Open in front of him is a copy of Leslie's Weekly, a woman's journal: pictures of baby basinettes, whale-bone corsets, fancy oil lamps, etc. Mary comes into scene to stand above him, looking down. Steve glances up and smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is that your kind of reading, Steve?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't read, Ma'am. I just look at the pictures.

direction.raw_text: ANGLED DOWN PAST Clay.

direction.raw_text: She glances up where Clay sits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You can't read?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your brother's always looked after you, hasn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since I can remember, Ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he just never troubled to have you get any schooling?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay. He listens, perturbed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary and Steve.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It wasn't Clay's fault. We've been moving around most all the time -- mebbe when we get the ranch and stay in one place I can learn my letters then -- MARY Don't you even know your letters?

direction.raw_text: Clay. He winces at!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, Ma'am.

direction.raw_text: Mary, Steve and Clay. Behind them, Clay rises and comes down nearer the fire.

direction.raw_text: She gives him a quick look of inquiry.

direction.raw_text: Steve looks up, then rises reluctantly.

dialogue.raw_text: Would you like to learn them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sure would.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I could start you out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That'd be swell. (shyly) You know, you're an awful lot different than I thought you'd be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're so nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did someone say I wasn't nice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no. Nobody said nothing to me. Only I got the idea that -- well Clay and me used to be walking through town and there was your place and through the window I could see you dancing, but Clay always took me over to the other side of the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Time to go to bed, Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Miss Wells.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good night, Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soft) There's a nice boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharp) That why you always took him on the other side of the street?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharper) Maybe I don't make the grade in some ways, but I know enough to teach a kid his letters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quiet) He doesn't know his letters, no -- but he knows the names of animals... he knows what roots to eat when you're clear out of food... He knows the difference between a possum and a coon just by lookin' at the tracks... more than most trappers know... and he can tell whether she'll rain or shine tomorrow by smelling the air tonight. There's a lot of things he doesn't know, I hope he'll never learn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning away) Like sticking his nose into other people's business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MOONLIGHT MED. SHOT. Clay reaches the top of the knoll and stands looking off. Below him the campfire burns low. Mary reaches the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANGLED PAST Mary TOWARD Clay. Mary stops, looking up. A match flares as Clay lights a cigarette. O.s. there is the SOUND of the bell mare's bell, the SOUND of horses moving restlessly. Mary turns, looks under the wagon.

direction.raw_text: Helen sits up and looks over at Elaine's side of the bed.

direction.raw_text: Mary straightens, moves down past the wagon, CAMERA PANNING WITH her. She calls softly.

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Elaine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was here a while ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Elaine!

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Clay. He looks down toward the wagon as Mary calls Elaine's name again, this time louder.

dialogue.raw_text: Elaine. (then) Clay -- Elaine's gone.

direction.raw_text: wagon. Clay stands with Mary at the wagon as Steve comes up. Helen is sitting up in bed, a comforter pulled around her.

dialogue.raw_text: She can't have gone far. I wasn't asleep long.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would she run off for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (excited) Because she's sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharp) Stay here. One woman wanderin' off's enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you worry, Miss Wells. We'll find her.

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mary) Build the fire up and stick close to it. Come on, Steve.

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MOONLIGHT Clay stops by the creek. Behind him the fire smoulders near the wagon. Mary's shadowy figure can be seen climbing the knoll where Clay's bedroll is. Helen is near the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve nods and splashes across the creek to follow the road leading west. Clay starts toward the meadow where the horses graze.

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed) Look around. She can't have gone far.

dialogue.raw_text: (calling) Elaine -- Elaine -- Elaine.

dialogue.raw_text: Elaine -- Elaine.

direction.raw_text: . This is rough country, the rocky hills covered sparsely with scrub pinon pine and brush. Steve stands on a rise. He looks around for a moment, then turning starts back down the slope. Suddenly he stops and listens, as from O.s. comes the SOUND of distant sobbing.

direction.raw_text: Steve. He listens, trying to locate the sound then he hurries down into a dry wash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve crashes through the brush into the wash, to stop beside Elaine who sits with her head buried in her arms, sobbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Steve and Elaine. Steve drops on his knees beside her. Elaine doesn't look up. Steve shakes her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls her up.

dialogue.raw_text: Ma'am -- you shouldn't have run off like that. Why I was just about to give up lookin'. Come on, now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't stay here. There's snakes and it's cold and you'll just get sicker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't care.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suppose that Lednov was to have found you, instead of me. Why you wouldn't have had a chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharp) I said I didn't care.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's botherin' you, anyway?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Runnin' off and worryin' people. Makin' it tougher on Clay than it is already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hysterical) Don't ask me because I won't tell you! I won't tell anybody! Go away!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't act so -- crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dully) I'm sorry. Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (relieved) That's a good girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WIDENS as he tucks her arm in the crook of his own and starts up the other side of the wash.

direction.raw_text: Steve, holding Elaine's arm, scrambles up the bank and through the brush.

direction.raw_text: He stops and looks off. Faintly O.s. is heard the SOUND of hoofbeats.

direction.raw_text: He shoves the girl down.

dialogue.raw_text: That's it. Watch out where you're steppin' --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That oughta be -- (then sharp) Down.

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - MOONLIGHT FULL SHOT - Clay reins his horse in and turns to look off in the direction from which the shot came. Faintly o.s. another shot echoes across the hills, then another and another. Clay spurs his horse and gallops off.

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT his ANGLE. Riding toward him are several horsemen. The horses move at a walk. One carries a double burden. Steve walks along behind. Clay spurs his horse and rides down toward them.

direction.raw_text: Clay, in the B.g., comes down the hill. The horsemen, seven of them, with Sheriff Gardner in the lead, followed by a deputy, carrying Elaine in front of him, file past camera. Steve, hands in his pockets, walks dejectedly in the dust cloud kicked up by the horses.

direction.raw_text: featuring Clay and Gardner. Clay reins in his horse beside Gardner, who also stops. The others rein in. Steve stops a short distance away.

direction.raw_text: He reins his horse around.

direction.raw_text: Clay looks back.

direction.raw_text: . TRAIL - DAY FADE IN EXTREME LONG SHOT. West are the Sierras and clouds are piled in untidy heaps on the range. The dusty trail runs through rolling country. Pinon pine and brush clothe the slopes. The wagon and horses are the moving center of a white cloud of dust.

dialogue.raw_text: Want to take her off our hands?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who shot who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody. The light was bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Steve's!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's she doin' runnin' around the country at night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't know. Did you ask her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All I can get out of her is she don't care about livin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look of things, she doesn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Keep a closer eye on her -- (motioning to Steve) And him. Shootin' going on, we'll never find Lednov.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was only three of them at first. I guess I lost my head.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) How'd you happen to miss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were quite a ways off and the wind was blowin'. I didn't have them to aim.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good thing you didn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man can't help gettin' excited once in a while.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right, Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I have my gun back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. You'll find it under the wagon seat. Like I said before, a twenty- two's more your size.

direction.raw_text: Clay's party. Clay rides in the lead. The wagon follows and Steve is riding beside the wagon. Behind is the remuda, and the horses are straying off the road in search of grass.

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? You went farther than that last time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm too old for it, Miss Wells... That's for little kids.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be silly... Nobody's too old to learn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (resolutely) Okay. A-B-C -- D-E-F -- G-H-I --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly) Oh, Steve!

direction.raw_text: Steve hesitates hoping he'll change his mind.

direction.raw_text: He wheels his horse and rides after Steve.

dialogue.raw_text: Get back to the horses. They're straggling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's learning his letters.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. While the horses wander all over the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sternly) Do like I said.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Learnin' to read has nothing to do with the right or the wrong side of the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (motioning) Are the horses stragglin' or aren't they?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a backward glance) They're stragglin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His letters will keep.

direction.raw_text: Steve is driving the horses back into the road. Clay rides up to help him. The horses fall in behind the wagon. Steve takes up his position in the rear. Clay rides over beside him.

direction.raw_text: CLAY AND STEVE. (MOVING)

direction.raw_text: They ride in silence for a moment.

dialogue.raw_text: Steve -- I want you to learn to read. I meant to teach you but I never seemed to find time. I figured when we got settled on the ranch we'd get around to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right with me if she teaches you, but I don't want you forgettin' your job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flat) I won't again.

direction.raw_text: One of the horses strays out of line and Clay rides out and gets the animal back in the road. Then he returns to Steve.

direction.raw_text: - (MOVING)

direction.raw_text: Steve looks over at his brother and finds a wry grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve smiles warmly at him.
