direction.raw_text: Cavalcade. It moves through dry barren hills. Far off, the Sierras rise against the sky Thunder heads are piled in untidy heaps on the range. DISSOLVE OUT EFFECT SHOT DISSOLVE IN sky. Dark rain clouds blown by a high wind. SOUND of thunder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't like other trips we've taken. For one thing, we've got a wagonload of women. For another there's a guy wanderin' around hopin' to put a bullet in my back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okeh, I was wrong. But you can't expect a fellow who never saw Lednov and never heard his name until a while ago to do too much worryin'. You've been sorta close mouthed about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess I have. You were pretty little when they locked him up. I don't suppose you even remember that time I was gone two months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I remember. You went to Mexico lookin' for cattle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods; then, after a moment) You remember Jeff Rawson? -- We used to go fishing and hunting with him when you were so high.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (offended) Sure I do. Went off down to Mexico or something...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I told you then. Only he didn't. Lednov killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh... that's the time you went away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) I caught up with Lednov in Nogales. He didn't like the idea of comin' back across the border but he came. I turned him over to the sheriff and -- that's the story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking off) Maybe you shoulda killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I should. But I was never much on killin'. Anyway, he moved too quick and I just got him through the shoulder. (glances off) Looks pretty peaceful up ahead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, it does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you never can tell. Why don't you get that new rifle out of the wagon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And while you're there you might as well find out what comes after K.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: rain -- the caravan. Clay leads it through a rain that has filled the ruts in the trail, soaked the horses to glistening black -- and obscures all view of the country through which they are passing. SOUND of rain falling is loud. Clay and Steve both wear slickers, gleaming from their shoulders to the rumps of their horses. Mary, a tarp around her shoulders, drives. Elaine and Helen huddle under a tarpaulin in the wagon bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT rain -- DOWN ANGLE -- wagon moving. Elaine sits up and, in her delirium, throws off the tarp. Helen tries to pull her down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CLOSE SHOT rain -- Clay. He wheels his horse at the SOUND of Helen's voice and rides back through the rain toward the wagon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (crying out) Elaine -- stop it --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT rain -- wagon. Mary pulls on the reins and the mules stop. Twisting them around the whip-stock, she swings back into the wagon bed. She looks up at Clay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In her anxiety, her tone is accusing. Clay drops the reins, climbs into the wagon and bends down beside Elaine. He puts his hand on her forehead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She should be in bed where it's dry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE rain - DOWN ANGLE - featuring Clay and Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts fixing the tarp so it gives more protection to the sick girl.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Yes, Ma'am, she should...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the nearest shelter's the Wyatt ranch and that's maybe five hours away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we get a doctor at that ranch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (straightening) No, Ma'am, we can't. We can get a roof and a fire and maybe Mrs. Wyatt knows something about taking care of sick people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: rain. Clay vaults out of the wagon and mounts his horse. Mary rises and climbs back into the seat. She lashes the mules with the reins. The wagon jolts forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT rain - ANGLED ACROSS seat - (MOVING). Clay rides alongside. Then, without a word, he strips off his slicker, tosses it on the seat and rides off. Mary looks after him, then at the slicker. She hesitates, not wanting to take favors from him. Then she pulls the slicker around her. Taking the whip, she hits the mules. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS and CAMERA HOLDS. The team breaks into a trot. The cavalcade moves away from camera through drenching rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WYATT RANCH - DAY LONG SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH gate in barbed wire fence. The ranch is nestled in a valley at the base of the Sierras. Green meadowland surrounds the farm buildings which consist of a cabin, barn and sheds, all in good repair and white- washed, as are the corral fences and the picket fence around the house, which stands in a clump of trees. The wind has pushed the clouds back over the hills, but far off there is still thunder. The gate in front f.g. is of barbed wire. It is closed. On the fence post a board is tacked. Neatly lettered on the board is the name:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From o.s. comes the SOUND of horses moving restlessly and the creaking of saddle leather, as a man swings out of the saddle. Footsteps approach. A man's head and shoulders, back to camera, comes into scene. He unloops the strand of bailing wire and lets the gate fall open, then turns and we see his face. He is Lednov. His cheek and jowls have a dark growth of beard. He wears a black leather jacket and a wrangler's grey hat. The clothes Forster was wearing. As he moves back to his horse, CAMERA PULLS BACK and PANS AROUND. His companions, McCall and Peters, also wear black leather jackets, sombre, dusty pants and hats. They are mounted on matched roans. The horses are winded, lathered and dirty. It is obvious they have ridden hard. Lednov strides forward and as he reaches for the reins the horse shies away. Brutally he jerks on the reins. The horse rears. He snatches his hat from his head and whacks the horse across the nose. McCall rides over and grabs the reins. Lednov scrambles into the saddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANGLED TOWARD gate. Lednov rides forward through the gate. His horse is limping badly. The others follow. They do not stop to put the gate back up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIL - DAY LONG SHOT. Clay's cavalcade moves forward along the trail. There are cloud patches overhead and faintly in the back country thunder rumbles. The mules pull the jolting wagons forward in a slow trot. Clay rides ahead. Steve and the remuda follow. DISSOLVE EXT. WYATT RANCH - DAY FULL SHOT. Lednov, McCall and Peters ride into the yard and up to the horses' trough. The horses plunge their muzzles deep into the trough. As the men dismount, Wyatt, a sinewy little man, hurries from the direction of the barn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at horse trough. Wyatt, smiling his pleasure, comes up as the three men dismount.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He extends his hand to Lednov. Lednov ignores it. The three men are looking around them. Two work horses, fat and elderly, amble across the corral to nuzzle the roans through the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wyatt is a little taken aback by Lednov's manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wyatt frowns up at Lednov, angered by the order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: McCall and Peters move closer to Wyatt, who glances around worriedly. Realizing he better do as he's told, he goes to the roan and rubs his ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bending, he lifts the horse's hoof. Lednov, McCall and Peters watch him. He drops the hoof, straightens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wyatt hesitates. Lednov steps toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He picks up the roan's reins and starts leading him into the corral. Lednov, with a jerk of his thumb, indicates that McCall is to go with him. McCall follows. Lednov and Peters turn toward the house.

dialogue.raw_text: (happily) My name's Wyatt. Certainly glad you boys dropped in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those the only horses you got?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, yes. They're all I need...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mine's gone lame. Take a look at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, we haven't got all day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoa, boy. Let's have a look.

dialogue.raw_text: He dropped a shoe. You shouldn't be ridin' him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put on another one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That won't help the stone bruise. You ain't been around horses much, looks like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you quit gabbin' and do what you're told.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (frightened, bewildered) All right, but it won't do much good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Lednov and Peters start for the house, Mrs. Wyatt, a woman of about fifty, small, plump, browned from the sun and hard from work, comes out on the porch. She has taken off her apron and holds it in her hand. She smiles at the two men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANGLED PAST Mrs. Wyatt. She starts down the steps as Lednov and Peters come up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At his tone, the welcoming smile leaves her face. She looks from one to the other. Lednov pushes past her up the steps and into the house. Mrs. Wyatt follows him with her glance. McCall motions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIL LONG SHOT. In the f.g. the cavalcade moves along the trail. Now the Sierras back of the Wyatt ranch are much closer. The sun has set but it is still light. DISSOLVE EXT. RANCH HOUSE - DAY MED. SHOT. Peters sprawls on the ground, smoking. He looks up as Wyatt and McCall cross from the direction of the barn.

direction.raw_text: Wyatt goes on past and hurries up the steps.

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT I was up to my elbows in flour when you boys rode up, that's why I din't come out sooner. I hope Ed asked you to stay the night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All we want's supper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're in a hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take care of that horse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gruffly) Yeah. The best I could.

direction.raw_text: . RANCH HOUSE ANGLED PAST Wyatt. This is the main room of the house -- a living room and kitchen combined: wood-stove against one wall, a sink with a pump against another, a fireplace, some simple furniture and, hanging from one of the rough walls, a concertina. Through an open doorway can be seen the Wyatt's bedroom. Another door, closed, leads into the second bedroom. The house has a warm, well-scrubbed look. Wyatt enters. Mrs. Wyatt, stoking the stove, turns. She glances nervously in the direction of the bedroom. Wyatt shifts his glance to the fireplace -- there is no gun hanging from the hooks above the mantel. Lednov appears in the doorway of the bedroom.

direction.raw_text: He crosses to the fireplace. He is carrying Wyatt's rifle, gun belt and six gun.

direction.raw_text: She crosses to him and stands in his way. Wyatt pushes past her and grabs for the guns. Lednov gives him a swipe with the back of his hand, knocking him away easily.

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Wyatt helps Ed to his feet. She puts an arm around him.

direction.raw_text: Lednov crosses to the cupboard and opens it. Finding the box of shells, he slips it in his pocket.

direction.raw_text: Wyatt and his wife look at each other. Then meekly they obey.

dialogue.raw_text: (fierce) I said I had a guy to see and I'm going to see him.

dialogue.raw_text: He gave me something once so I wouldn't forget.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) He says go, we go.

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT Hush, Ed. Hush. They might come back.

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT. The three men mount their horse, dig their spurs in and ride away. As they ride toward the gate, Wyatt comes out on the steps.

direction.raw_text: . Here the trail passes through a narrow draw, then climbs a small rise which overlooks the gate. Clay's caravan jogs along the trail.

direction.raw_text: . The caravan climbs toward camera. CAMERA PANS AROUND to SHOOT DOWN TOWARD the Wyatt ranch. Through the gate ride Lednov, McCall and Peters. They stop for a moment then turn right and trot along the fence line. As they disappear, the SOUND of the caravan's approach is heard o.s.

direction.raw_text: . It is a pleasant room with a large, handmade, double bed, white flour sack curtains at wide windows. Mrs. Wyatt puts the lamp on the dresser. Going to the bed she pulls back the covers, feels the sheets.

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT (calling) Wrap a stove lid in dish towels and bring it in here. This bed's like ice.

direction.raw_text: Turning from the bed, she crosses to the dresser. Beside the dresser is a camel-back trunk. She starts to open a dresser drawer, pauses and looks down at the trunk. Moving to the trunk, she hesitates. Then making up her mind, she bends down and throws open the trunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT DOWN ANGLE. A girl's clothing is neatly packed in the trunk. A framed picture is face down on top of the clothing. Mrs. Wyatt kneels by the trunk, pushes the dresses aside and finds a nightgown. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS as she rises and shakes it out. It is frilly, dainty, very feminino; obviously the nightdress of a young girl. She closes the trunk, turns and as she goes to the bed, Wyatt comes through the door carrying the towel-wrapped stove lid. She lays the nightgown on the bed, takes the stove lid and puts it between the sheets. Wyatt is staring down at the garment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They face each other. Wyatt reaches out and takes the nightgown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wyatt opens the trunk, puts the nightgown in and closes the lid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The slamming of a door o.s. interrupts them. They turn and start for the door.

direction.raw_text: She follows Wyatt to the doorway, CAMERA DOLLYING WITH her. She stops in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (cold) Put it back.

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT Someone might as well get some good out of it. Wyatt crosses to the trunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT It isn't as if she was dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cold) It stays there, understand!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT (calling) Right in here, Mr. Phillips.

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT The bed's all ready and warm --

direction.name: direction

Clay suddenly realizes that something is wrong. He glances up. Elaine opens her eyes and looks up at her mother and father.

direction.raw_text: Wyatt doesn't move.

direction.raw_text: As Clay waits, Wyatt moves through the door unable to argue back.

direction.raw_text: . Mary and Helen stand close to the steve, looking anxiously toward the bedroom door as Clay and Wyatt come out. Clay closes the door. Wyatt, dazed by the shock of seeing his daughter again, stands momentarily staring at the closed door. Then very slowly he turns and looks at Helen and Mary.

Then he enters and closes the door softly. Helen looks over at Mary and smiles.

direction.raw_text: as Wyatt stops, looking at Elaine, resting back against the pillow, seeming very young in the nightgown. For a moment it is difficult to know what is in Wyatt's mind. Then he sees the twin tintypes. CAMERA MOVES TOWARD Wyatt's face as tears come to his eyes.

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) You don't have to explain. Did I tell you how grateful I am for what you've done?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't leave you sitting by the road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could have treated us like they did in Aspen. No. You wouldn't do a thing like that -- it isn't in you to be mean or cruel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Mary in f.g.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turning, she leans against the post that supports the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay puts his cup down, looks up. She is very lovely standing in the moonlight, her body arched back, the robe open a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Straightening, she crosses the porch to pause momentarily close to Clay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She enters the house. Clay looks after her, smiling faintly. He knows she is up to something but not what.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) No man who brings up a kid like you've brought up Steve could ever be cruel to people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope you get everything you want out of life -- CLAY (wary) Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've earned it -- the horse ranch on the Toulomoe -- the girl in the spotted gingham.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should know. She's in your dream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ever since you've looked after Steve you've had the dream -- a ranch on the river -- good grass, good water, barn corral and house --- that part you've shared with Steve. The girl in gingham you plan sneakin' in when he isn't looking. (she pauses)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (enigmatic) Go on. Tell me more about her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She wears this gingham dress -- cooks popovers -- makes jam in season -- makes her own soap from pig fat and wood ashes and has cheeks the color of red apples.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) I'll make the soap myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But the rest is right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will she be dark or fair?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Blonde as a new mop. And beautiful as the girl on a feed store calendar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) I hope you find her -- because, like I said, you've earned your dream. Goodnight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Save for the moonlight coming through the window, the room is dark. Mary enters softly, throws off her robe and slips into bed beside Helen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE on bed. Moonlight falls across the bed. Mary pulls the covers up. Helen turns her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary snuggles down on the pillow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN - MORNING MED. LONG SHOT - ANGLED THROUGH window PAST Mary. The early morning sun fills the yard. Steve is in the corral harnessing the mules. Clay and Wyatt are taking Mary's and Helen's trunks out of the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary, who was in profile, turns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you make it interesting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tried my best, but these things take time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And we're running out of that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's still tomorrow morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those trunks look like ours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Helen is seated at the table. Mary stands with her back to the window near the sink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary comes over to stand by the table. Her expression is thoughtful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen rises. Her manner is determined.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How long do you think we'll have to stay here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Until Pa gets around to driving us to Minden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't want to go there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No we don't. But that's where we're going. From Minden we take a stage to Reno, then another one over to Auburn and another one to Placerville. Then it's a day's trip to Sonora.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay could save us an awful lot of time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He certainly could. About a month.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you waiting for? Do something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharp) You're not giving up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many ways can a man say no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (crosses to door) Maybe I better start working on him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd think he'd do it for Elaine's sake, at least...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as she stops, apparently inspired by Mary's last remark. She looks out into the yard where Clay is working on the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING TOWARD Elaine's bedroom door. Helen crosses to Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts her arm around Mary's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she speaks she edges Mary to the door leading outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary smiles at her, shrugs and exits. Helen looks after her. Mary's footsteps are heard going down the steps. Then Helen swings around and going to Elaine's door, opens it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sweetly) If you can't bring him around, nobody can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on. Have another try at him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the use.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cajoling) Please. Maybe he'll take a good look at you and stop thinking so much about his horses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A man has only so many no's in him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . ELAINE'S BEDROOM MED. SHOT. Elaine is sitting up in bed. There is a small table by the bed and on it is a breakfast tray. Mrs. Wyatt sits by the bed. Elaine looks happy for the first time. Mrs. Wyatt is holding a cup to her lips. Helen enters and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Crossing to the bed she takes the cup from Mrs. Wyatt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she pushes Mrs. Wyatt toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She closes the door behind Mrs. Wyatt and comes back, sits on the edge of the bed and holds the cup to Elaine's lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine tries not to show her panic at this suggestion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine pushes the cup away, sits up straighter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine buries her head in the pillow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elaine sits up and grabs Helen's arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opens and Mrs. Wyatt enters. She hurries over to the bed, pushes Helen aside, and takes the sobbing girl in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Wyatt flares at Helen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turning, she goes to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look at you, sitting up already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me do this while you get some breakfast.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT But I like to do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're worn out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now don't argue. You've got two able- bodied girls to help you so take advantage of it. And don't let me catch you touching the dishes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well -- it's going to be good for all of us -- having a nice long rest here. After all -- Sonora will still be there next month. Maybe we can rehearse a new number -- try it out on your folks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Helen -- why don't you and Mary go on with Clay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He won't take us. (then, hurt) Don't you want us around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course I do -- but it'd be better for you -- and the house is kind of small -- HELEN If you're worried about Mary and me talkin' too much, don't. No matter how many questions your old man asks. We know how to keep our mouths shut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It isn't that -- HELEN Don't talk -- eat -- we want to get you well quick as we can so we can all get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I want to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drink this and stop being silly. Why would anyone want to live in this place. You might as well be dead and buried. Nothing to do but look at mountains. In a week you'd be talking to yourself. (then, brightly) Maybe that's what got you started in the first place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (distraught) I'm not going anywhere. I'm staying here where I belong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not if I know Mary. When she rides into Sonora, you'll be with her. And mighty glad to be there after this. I don't see how you stood it as long as you did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobbing) Stop it -- stop it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (contrite) Darling -- now I've got you all upset.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go away -- please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right -- you go back to sleep. Tomorrow when you feel better things will look a whole lot different. Don't you worry about anything -- Mary's going to talk things over with your folks --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (fiercely) She mustn't -- don't you let her -- HELEN There, there. Don't you upset yourself -- ELAINE (wildly) If she says anything to them I'll kill her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobbing) I don't want to leave you, ever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . WYATT What did you do to her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. The poor child's worried about Mary --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won't let her say anything --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN MED. SHOT. Leaving the door open, Helen enters the kitchen. She glances back at the bedroom, half smiling, then crosses to the window and looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . YARD ANGLED past Helen THROUGH window. Clay is crossing the yard toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN MED. SHOT. Helen turns from the window and walks hurriedly to the second bedroom door. Clay's footsteps cross the porch. Helen enters the bedroom and closes the door as Clay comes in. Clay looks around, then seeing the open bedroom door, crosses to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ELAINE'S BEDROOM ANGLED PAST Clay in doorway. Mrs. Wyatt is holding the sobbing girl in her arms. She looks over at Clay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then realizing that something is wrong he steps into the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm off --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: CLAY (puzzled) What's the matter? Hearing his voice, Elaine lifts her head from her mother's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay looks from one to the other, frowning. Elaine tries to get out of bed. Her mother holds her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turning, he exits. Mrs. Wyatt holds Elaine close.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't let them stay here, Mr. Phillips. They'll spoil everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wildly) Take them with you -- Mary's going to talk to dad -- she's going to keep talking and talking to me until maybe I won't want to stay here -- MRS. WYATT Please take them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't -- ELAINE You've got to -- don't you understand -- they want me with them and they'll fix it so I have to go -- CLAY (sharp) No they won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PORCH MED. SHOT. Helen stands on the porch in the sunlight. She glances back. Clay, his expression hard and angry comes out. He doesn't look at Helen but stalks down the steps toward the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What comes after Z?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's the end of the line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (happily) Then I know my alphabet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From A to Z. All you have to do now is figure out what they mean put together in words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay comes toward the wagon. Helen stands on the porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay appears behind her. Mary turns and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He catches Clay's glance and his face falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve gets some courage. He comes over to his brother and faces him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses; Clay waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay moves past them toward the corral. Mary looks after him, then turning, motions to Helen. Helen starts toward the wagon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And that's tough, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Without someone to teach you, it's tough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He knows his alphabet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll bet I'd be reading in a week if --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe Clay will take up where I left off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think it's fair --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leaving them here when we could just as well take them. We got plenty of room in the wagon. And -- and -- they cook and drive the mules. They don't bother anybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finished, son?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weakly) There's only two of them now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay's horse stands saddled at the fence. He vaults into the saddle, turns the horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rides off. Steve, delighted, runs to start loading the girls' things. Helen hurries into the scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll round up the horses. Throw that junk in the wagon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Mary and Helen. Mary smiles at Helen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen nods, looking at Mary as though in admiration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . WYATT RANCH LONG SHOT - the wagon, followed by the remuda and with Clay riding ahead moves slowly up the canyon back of the ranch. FADE OUT EXT. FOREST TRAIL - DAY FADE IN LONG SHOT - ANGLED WEST. The forest is fairly open, yellow pine, lodgepole and fir. To the West can be seen the bald red granite domes of the higher range. O.s. there is the SOUND of the cavalcade approaching. CAMERA PANS AROUND and ANGLES PAST. Toward camera, comes the cavalcade, climbing slowly. Far in the distance and down can be seen the waste of desert and the barren hills of Nevada. Clay, a rifle across his legs, is riding on one side of the wagon. Steve rides beside Mary, who is driving. The remuda trails behind. Helen, lying in the wagon bed, cannot be seen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (happily) You were right -- a man has only so many no's in him. But he had me worried -- that last one sounded so final.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TRUCKING SHOT ANGLED PAST Steve. Steve has a copy of Leslie's Weekly open on the pommel. Helen lies full length in the wagon bed, occupying herself by giving herself a manicure with an orange stick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay glances over at his brother. Mary sees him watching. Their eyes meet. She smiles. He doesn't return the smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sighs and scowls down at the page. He puts his finger on a word and starts to spell it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary starts to protest -- Steve goes on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's a lot tougher than I figured. Knowin' my letters is one thing. But makin' sense out of words is harder'n trackin' weasel after rain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: and even if I do learn to read, what use'll it be? I'm goin' to live on a ranch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's plenty of use for reading -- you'll see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: U-n-i-c-o-r-n-... What in heck's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Unicorn -- a kind of animal -- STEVE What do they look like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmmm... sort of like a horse -- with a horn in the center of its forehead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Horses with horns! Huh! Do we have 'em in Nevada?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about California?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would they be good to eat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not too sure) Kind of tough, I guess... But you're not liable to hunt them -- I don't think there's any alive now, anyways -- and I'm not sure but I don't think there ever were...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then if they wasn't alive, how can they be an animal?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An' if you can't hunt 'em and even if you could they'd be tough, what's the use of knowin' how to spell them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't read to fill your stomach... Poetry, for instance. All the poems in the world wouldn't fill you half as much as a bowl of eatmeal -- but they make you feel good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stubbornly) I feel good anyways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ANGLED PAST Clay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He touches his horse with his spurs and rides on ahead.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't go arguing with your teacher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not, but there's some of it I don't see any sense to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a lot of things I don't see any sense to. But make up your mind. Learn to read or -- (motioning)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: go back and watch the horses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE ANGLED PAST Mary. Steve in the b.g. Mary looks after Clay, puzzled, wondering. Then she looks over at Steve.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Steve?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grinning) Now I know what a unicorn is, what do we do next?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Here the forest has thinned out. The trail climbs a rise, then drops down. Clay jogs along the trail, his rifle across his knees. As he reaches the edge of the forest at the crest of the rise, he suddenly pulls his horse to a stop, swings around and rides back into the trees. Throwing the reins over the horse's head, he swings out of the saddle and moves cautiously to the crest of the hill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay's ANGLE. The trail leads down through open country to a big meadow ringed with lodgepole pine, and across the meadow to start climbing toward another, higher range of hills. Three horsemen on roans, Lednov, Peters and McCall, are crossing the meadow slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DOWN ANGLE. Lednov, Peters and McCall as they ride across the meadow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay, as he peers down. He cocks his rifle. The voices of Mary and Steve and the SOUND of the approaching wagon can be heard o.s. Clay turns his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the cavalcade. Mary and Helen are in the seat of the wagon. Steve rides alongside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT Clay. He lowers his rifle, waves at them to stop and be quiet, rises and hurries down the hill, CAMERA PANNING WITH him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MEADOW MED. SHOT of Lednov as he pulls in his limping horse, steps, looking back over his shoulder as though he sensed an unfamiliar presence. The other two watch him, frowning. Then he shrugs and glances down at the bad leg of his mount.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they start away, moving slowly toward the trees in the distance...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We'll camp on up ahead away. That leg ain't good...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT Clay motions to Mary to stop as he hurries toward the wagon. Mary reins in the mules.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HILLTOP - DUSK DISSOLVE IN LONG SHOT. Clay, in close foreground, stands, leaning on his rifle. The sun has set and the valley below is in shadow. There is the silence of dusk. No wind stirs the trees. There is some light outlining the high mountains -- treeless crags and domes and spires. Clay turns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We're staying here until dark. (motioning) Pull over to the woods. (to Steve) You put hobbles on the horses -- all of 'em. Get goin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Down the hill in the forest, is the wagon. Beyond it the horses stand. Steve is stretched out on his stomach studying his magazine. Helen is sitting on a tarp playing solitaire. Clay starts down the hill toward the camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay walks through the trees. As he comes around a big yellow pine, he stops suddenly and looks down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE ANGLED DOWN PAST Clay. Mary lies on the carpet of pine needles, her head pillowed on her arms, her dress pulled taut across her chest. She is looking up through the trees at the fading sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay stares down at Mary. She does not look at him. She is aware of his presence, but she doesn't show it. In the soft light of dusk she is very lovely. Clay is conscious of her lovliness. He would like to drop down beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary. She turns her face to look at him. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. Clay stands above her, looking down. For a moment their eyes meet. Clay starts away. CAMERA HOLDS ON Mary.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where you goin'? Over to the other side of the street?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ANGLED PAST Mary, who rises slowly. Clay looks back, hesitates, then crosses to where the horses are tethered and starts saddling his mare. Mary moves down toward him through the trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay tightens the cinch. Mary moves up to stand beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He swings into the saddle, pulls the rifle out of the scabbard and lays it across the pommel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He touches the mare with his spurs and trots down the hill. He disappears around a bend in the trail.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are we leaving?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's too light yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better go on back and get some more sleep. You'll need it later on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soberly) You're not going out to look for them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm not. All I want 'em to do is keep ahead of us -- a long way ahead. So I'm riding up the line aways to pick us out a new trail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mary, in the f.g., is staring after Clay. Helen is watching her. Steve has risen and walks up behind her. He smiles at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts down toward the wagon, Steve walking beside her and CAMERA TRUCKING WITH them THROUGH the forest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary glances over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have passed Helen, playing solitaire on the canvas, and have reached the place where the grub box stands. Steve spreads a tarp for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary sits down. Steve opens the grub box and takes out some plates, tinned food and hardtack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands her a plate of food, takes another and goes over to Helen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody's gonna catch him sleeping. Don't worry about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning) Oh, I wasn't worrying. (flustered) I saw him saddling up and thought he was ready to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) You were worryin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sometimes not knowin' how to read has its points. You can't read books so you look at people and figure 'em out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you've got me all figured out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll fix us somethin' to eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like when you were standin' there looking after Clay. I knew right off what you were thinking. Because I've been watching you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were supposed to be reading words.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was doin' both. Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Helen looks up from her card game, takes the plate with a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grins at her, turns and comes back to Mary who is watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve sits on the edge of the grub box and picks up his plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve looks over at her, embarrassed, a little hurt by her tone. He rises, takes Mary's empty plate and his own and goes over to the little spring to wash them. Mary looks sharply at Helen. Helen shrugs. Mary rises and follows Steve over to the spring.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Steve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better not let Clay catch you waitin' on us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't pay any attention to him. That's his way and I've found he's sure easy to get along with. I don't recollect him havin' hit me more'n a couple of times and I guess I had it comin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But you're his brother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He'll treat his wife just as good. Maybe better. Ever see him use a bull snake on the mules like other wranglers?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir, Clay's nice to be around. (the clincher) He don't chew much and when he does he spits outside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) You make him sound wonderful... Go on. Tell Mary more about him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE ON SPRING Steve kneels by the little pool, washing the plates in the run off. Mary stops above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kneels beside him. Steve looks over at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks down at the water bubbling up into the little moss lined pool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIL - NIGHT CLOSE SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. O.s. there is the SOUND of the cavalcade moving. A wheel passes camera, then another. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal the wagon passing in the moonlit darkness. Mary is driving.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She was only teasin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (offhand) Oh, sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like to do things for you. Didn't you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) I know now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay rides into the shot, his rifle ready. The wagon follows. Then the remuda with Steve bringing up the rear. Steve also holds his rifle ready. Both men are wary, watchful, apprehensive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FOREST - NIGHT FULL SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. SHOOTING DOWN THROUGH the leaves of a quaking aspen. The cavalcade moves on along the trail. DISSOLVE EXT. ROCKY HILLSIDE - DAWN FULL SHOT. The east is grey with the approaching dawn. The terrain is treeless, forbidding. Granite crags rise all around. The trail leads up through a canyon then narrows along the edge of a cliff. The cavalcade toils forward. Clay, in the lead, stops and waits for the wagon to come abreast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the wagon comes abreast, Clay dismounts, loops the reins over the tail gate, then swings up into the seat, motioning for Mary to move over. He takes the reins, puts his rifle down in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE - MOVING (PROCESS) Clay and Mary. Helen is sleeping in the bed of the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary glances ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She picks up the rifle and holds it across her knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary glances over at him wonderingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They ride along in silence for a moment. The trail is rough. The jolting wagon throws them together. Their shoulders touch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary studies him, trying to figure out what he means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay is busy with driving down the rough road. He speaks without looking at her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you trust me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not on this trail, I don't. I've been over it before. Anyway, you ought to be pretty sleepy. Why don't you climb in back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like to see where I'm going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Did you ever care where you were goin' or where you'd been?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe not! But I want to get there in one piece.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Why did you change your mind about bringing us along?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soberly) I don't know. I thought I did. Now I'm not sure. I thought it had something to do with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it did. It had a great deal to do with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just how do you mean that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know so much about me -- figure it out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So that's it -- (he glances over) You think I was making fun of your girl in gingham.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Helen. She lies in the bed of the wagon, looking up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She waits for an answer, but getting none, continues.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I wasn't. And I wasn't making fun of you or your dream.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, maybe I was trying to get you to do something you didn't want to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - MOVING (PROCESS) Clay and Mary. Clay busies himself with the brake and the reins.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't do a thing like that, would you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Yes. But -- that was the other night. Now -- I don't think I would.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT - ANGLED AHEAD Clay and Mary in f.g. The trail now goes down a slope to a river, which boils out of a narrow canyon, then follows the river through the canyon. Clay hands the reins to Mary, takes his rifle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's the West Walker. Take it easy now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay swings down. The wagon moves past him. He frees his horse, swings into the saddle and gallops down toward the canyon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary. She looks after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The wagon moves down toward the river. Clay disappears into the canyon. Steve and the remuda follow the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CANYON TRAIL ANGLED TOWARD mouth of canyon. Clay rides along the trail, his rifle at the ready. Now he moves warily, keeping a sharp lookout. The canyon is dark, sinister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cavalcade enters the canyon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay rides toward camera. The trail curves around a cliff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay. He rides around the bend in the trail. He hears something. He reins the horse in. Some pebbles rattle down the cliff. He looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The muzzle of a rifle is visible. Clay starts to bring his gun up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hold it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay lets his rifle rest across his knees. He looks up. Fowler, a well-set-up young man in jeans, blue shirt and worn jacket and wearing a battered hat, moves into scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay. He is wary, puzzled as to the man's identity. For all he knows it may be one of Lednov's men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay and Fowler.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doin' on this trail?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Followin' it. Any reason I shouldn't?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT SHOOTING PAST Fowler. Into view comes the wagon and the remuda. Fowler lowers his rifle. He slides down the cliff to stand beside Clay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Clay and Fowler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He extends his hand. Clay shakes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He motions ahead, starts walking. Clay rides beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MEADOW FULL SHOT. The river is beyond the meadow. In the pine forest at the edge of the meadow is Fowler's camp. The cavalcade is driving up to the camp. There are two horses tethered in the meadow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: My name's Fowler. I'm camped up a ways.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clay Phillips of Aspen. Been havin' trouble?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope. But I don't want any.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neither do we. That's why we took this trail instead of the main road, and drove all night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're welcome to use my camp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT. A tarp is stretched over the camp. There is a crude stone fireplace, a rough table and two benches. Shelves are nailed between the trees. In a small lean-to there is a bunk with Fowler's bedroll on it. Fowler stands watching Mary and Holen as they get out of the wagon. The horses sproad out across the meadow. Steve and Clay dismount. Both unsaddle. Helen, Mary and Fowler exchange glances. Then the two women walk toward the camp, which is behind a screen of trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE ON CAMP Helen and Mary enter the camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She goes off and across the meadow. Mary looks after her, shrugs and going to the fireplace, takes moss and twigs from the pile and puts them in. Clay, carrying saddle bags and canteens, enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts them down, goes over to the fireplace and kneels to light the moss. Mary has stepped back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We might as well start a fire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go ahead. (nodding off) Get in training for the pioneer life. I'm finding the nearest body of water and climbing into it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got a light?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As he lights the fire, the lower portion of Mary's body comes into the shot. Clay becomes aware of her closeness. He rises slowly. CAMERA ANGLES UP. Mary is standing facing him, almost touching him. They stare at each other without speaking. Both suddenly move togother. They kiss. There is a SOUND over shot and they step apart, looking off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve has come into scene and is looking at them. He smiles with pleasure and surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve nods, smiles at both of them and goes out of scene. Clay and Mary face each other. Suddenly Clay swings around and goes out of shot after his brother.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (innocently) Want the wagon unloaded, Clay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (upset) Just the grub box and bed rolls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She looks after him, clearly in love, disappointed that they were interrupted. Then she turns to the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT Clay and Steve. CAMERA MOVES AHEAD of them as they walk toward the wagon. Steve has begun to whistle blithely. Clay looks sideways at him. Steve whistles even louder. They stop at the wagon. CAMERA HOLDS. Steve climbs inside and hands down the grub box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay puts the grub box on the ground. Steve tosses out the bed rolls, then jumps out. He grins up at Clay.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think it'll be swell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Clay, embarrassed, puts his hand on the boy's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve watches him, puzzled. His exuberance has gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abruptly Clay turns and indicates the grub box. Steve watches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve nods and carries the grub box out of the scene. Clay stares after him. Then he picks up the bed roll and moves around the wagon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When you get older you'll understand things better. Like women and men. Just because a man kisses a woman, doesn't always mean -- well, he can kiss her and not want to -- have her around all the time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got a lot to do, you and I. Gettin' that ranch started and everything. We've been getting along fine, all these years. For a while I want to keep it the way it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take that in and help her get breakfast, will you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay in the f.g. In front of Clay stretches the meadow with the river beyond. The horses are grazing in the meadow. Fowler can be seen hurrying toward the aspens and alders that screen the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RIVER BANK MED. SHOT. Here the river moves quietly down. The bank is sandy. Alders and aspens screen it from the meadow. Helen sits on the sand taking off her shoes and stockings. Her toilet box is beside her. Something on the bank catches her attention, she rises and climbs the bank. Some branches of aspen cover an object. She pulls the branches away, revealing a crud, miner's cradle or rocker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Helen stares down at the cradle. She doesn't know what it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen, startled, turns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sharp) What are you doing down here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Fowler and Helen. They stare at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She glances from Fowler to the cradle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurriedly he covers it with branches again. Helen watches him, curious, interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When Fowler doesn't explain she moves on down the bank and sits on the sand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fowler comes over and sits down beside her. He takes [a] sack of tobacco and papers from his pocket. She reaches for them. He watches her wide-eyed as she rolls a cigarette. He holds a match for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns to the toilet case on the sand beside her, takes out a comb. He glances at the box, then reaches over and from it takes her powder box. He sniffs it. Without irritation, as though borrowing a toy from a child, Helen takes the powder box from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him then up the bank where the cradle is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fowler hesitates. Helen hands him back the powder box as matter-of-factly as she took it. He accepts it gratefully, again putting it to his nose. Now he looks up at her, regarding her calculatingly for a moment or two. Their eyes meet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches to his throat and lifts over his head a braided loop of rawhide. Attached to the loop is a small, plump, soft-leather poke. Still holding the powder box, he passes her the poke. She starts to work with the thong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen still struggles with the thong. He takes the poke, pulls it open, pouring grains of gold into his palm. Helen looks at the shining heap in his hand. Then she takes the poke and pours some of the grains in her own palm. She looks down at it. Her expression is calculating. She looks up at Fowler and then the hard look goes away. She gives him a soft smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MEADOW CLOSE SHOT - DOWN ANGLE. Mary is asleep in the shade of a pine. She lies on a tarp using a folded blanket for a pillow. It is very quiet. She stirs, opens her eyes. Her expression changes. A soft smile plays around her lips as CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS and we see Clay sitting near her, leaning against the bole of a pine. He isn't looking at her. Mary watches him for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay looks over at her. Then rising he moves closer, squats and rolls a cigarette. He holds it out. She licks it, then puts it in her mouth. Clay lights a match, holds it out. She catches his hand and holds the flame to her cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She still holds his hand. They look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She holds his hand, smiling up. Clay hesitates, then desire for her is more than he can bear, so he takes her in his arms. They kiss, holding the kiss for a long while.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (curt) You got no business snoopin' around -- HELEN (hard) Me snoopin'? I came down here to take a bath.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That something I shouldn't see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flustered) No. But it's mine and I didn't want anyone foolin' with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a thing I was workin' on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The way you act, it must be something pretty secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on. Take your bath. I'll beat it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't have a smoke on you, would you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That sure smells good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Up here in the hills, a man gets a hankering to smell powder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why stay in the hills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess you can keep a secret. That's a gold rocker. I'm doin' a little placer mining in a place nobody ever thought to look for gold before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at her -- see her shine. One week's work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (softly) Roll me a cigarette, Clay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you wake me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should have. I don't like leaving things unfinished.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quiet) Maybe it's better that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (intense) You don't mean that Clay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They break. She lies looking up. He half lies, half sits beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For answer, Clay kisses her again -- hard, ruthlessly. His hands crush her shoulders. Mary holds the kiss for a moment, then draws back, waiting for him to say the words she wants to hear. His hands pull her toward him. Mary wants the kiss -- but she also wants a declaration of love. She makes one last try to get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay's grip on her shoulders tightens. She searches his face with a glance -- stares into his eyes -- then pushes him away and sits up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (a whisper) Tell me, darling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does a man usually tell a girl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me -- please --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mary. She is hurt by his silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right you don't love me. So let it go at that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WIDENS. Clay's expression hardens. He drops his hands from her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stands. He rises to face her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turning she starts down toward camp.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What did you expect? Speeches I don't mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't expect anything. A minute ago I hadn't cuite waked up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm awake now. Go on. Say what you want to say. I'll listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If it's pretty speeches you want, you won't be hearing them. Even when I mean 'em, they don't come easy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Save 'em for the girl in gingham. Just tell me I'm not good enough for you. Go on. Say a woman like me can't change.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right -- it's said!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then let's get started. The sooner I get to Sonora, the better I'll like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT ANGLED PAST Clay. Below is the camp. Beyond the camp, through the trees, stands the wagon and Steve is hitching up the mules. Clay hesitates, then follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: TRUCKING SHOT Mary. Tears form in her eyes. She blinks them away, composing herself with an effort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAMP MED. SHOT - Helen and Fowler in f.g. Helen sits at one side of the table, Fowler on the other. Helen holds the soft leather poke. In the b.g. Mary approaches. Behind her comes Clay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen pours the gold out in her palm as Mary comes up. Mary stands looking down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're sure there's more where this came from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Plenty more. (motioning) And somewhere up there's the lode, the rock rotten with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty, isn't it? And all you have to do is shovel sand into a thing and the river does the work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Clay enters the scene and goes over to pick up his saddle bags.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reaches over and pats Fowler's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary looks from Helen to Fowler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary stands looking down at Helen. Lovingly Helen pours the gold back in the poke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay, saddle bags in hand, straightens. Mary directs the rest of the speech at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen juggles the poke in her hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quiet) Give it back to him. We're leavin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you are. I'm not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm stayin' here with Jed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shyly) I figure we'll get along just fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well cheer, why don't you? No more responsibilities, Mary. Marcia -- Elaine -- me -- all taken care of. Down there feeding horses and raising kids, you won't have a thing to worry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not raising horses or kids for anybody. I'm opening the slickest gambling house in California with a crystal chandelier, the biggest you ever saw --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gaslights and a dance floor and a big bar. Cash registers with bells and a couple of boys with armbands just to keep 'em ringing. What do you think of that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sounds fine. Only that isn't how it's going to be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sure of this. But not of you. (shakes head) You won't open any joint. I've been watching you change. You're mad now and you think you can change back. But you can't. You'll end up making beds in a boarding house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (furious) That's it then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the master) That's it. She's staying with me -- for keeps.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Steve has entered the camp and is standing looking at them open-mouthed. Mary moves over to Fowler and holds out her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay moves up beside Mary.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If there were more men like you, there wouldn't be so many of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's nice to meet a man who doesn't want to own a woman from the day she was born. I never had the luck. The only kind I've run into were tramps or dirty-minded hypocrites.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Clay, Mary and Fowler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves on past her, motions to Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steve hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stalks away, followed by Steve. Mary turns and looks after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Fowler) She's aimin' at me, but her aim's bad. (to Mary) Want to know why I changed my mind about bringing you? Because I talked to Elaine -- because I was afraid to leave you with decent people, that's why. And you'll open your joint all right. You wouldn't fit anywhere else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's round up the horses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharp) Come on -- we don't want to keep the people in Sonora waiting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mary. She wants to break windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT Mary, Fowler and Helen. Helen is staring at Mary. She crosses to her and puts her arm around her shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary throws her arm off and moves after Clay and Steve. Helen looks at Fowler and shrugs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mary, Honey. I talked too much, like always -- he thinks you told Elaine the things I told her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (furious) I don't care what he thinks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the wagon. As Mary hurries up to stand by the tail gate, Clay and Steve, now mounted, spur their horses and start across the meadow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary. She stares after them, raging. Then she glances at the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary in f.g. The mulos stand in their traces, waiting. Mary makes up her mind what to do. Climbing into the bed, she heaves out pack saddles, bed rolls, ropes, etc. Clay and Stove can be seen in b.g. riding down toward where the horses graze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANGLED TOWARD camp. Into the scene come pack saddles, bed rolls. Helen and Fowler, in b.g., walk toward the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT wagon. Mary straightens, looks off, then climbs into the seat and picks up the reins and the whip. She lashes the mules with the whip. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. The mules jump and gallop off. Fowler and Helen come into the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the wagon, pulled by the galloping mules, is disappearing in a cloud of dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the meadow. Clay and Steve have almost reached the horses. Steve turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay swings around.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Clay -- look!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: their ANGLE. Mary drives the wagon around a bend in the trail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT ON Clay. He glances after Mary, then reins his horse around and gallops after her, CAMERA PANNING WITH him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRAIL MOVING SHOT. Mary drives the wagon along the trail. Ahead beyond the river, the mountains rise. The river is running bank full. The trail leads down to a rocky, dangerous bank. Mary pulls the mules in at the bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary. She looks toward the river. She is frightened, about to abandon the whole foolish enterprise. She glances back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FROM Mary's ANGLE. Clay gallops around a bend in the trail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary. She looks in Clay's direction, then turns and stares at the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANGLED PAST Mary. She makes up her mind to go through with it and lashes the mules with the whip. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. The mules balk when they reach the river. Mary lashes them again. They jump forward into the torrent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay gallops toward the river. Steve comes around the bend in the trail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT the river. The mules flounder, start swimming. The current catches the wagon. It starts drifting downstream. Mary whips the mules. They swim, the current pulls them. Then the wagon goes over. Mary is thrown into the water. The mules kick themselves free and swim to the other bank. Mary goes under, comes up and starts swimming desperately. Clay rides into the SHOT. His mare hesitates at the bank. Clay spurs her and she plunges in. Mary's belongings can be seen floating down the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay swims his horse toward Mary who is floundering in the stream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary. The current sweeps her against a rock. Stunned -- she goes under.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay swims his horse to her, reaches down and lifts her up in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay's horse, with the double burden, fights her way out of the stream and scrambles up the bank to stop on level ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE Clay and Mary. Clay, his expression anxious, stares down at the stunned Mary. He swings out of the saddle, holding her tenderly to him. The brush with death has made him realize how much she means to him. Gently, he puts her down on the sand, stoops beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay and Mary in f.g. Steve swims his horse across and rides up the bank to dismount near them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MED. CLOSE - DOWN ANGLE Mary opens her eyes and sits up
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary is humiliated, bedraggled and wet, still angry and fighting back tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary gets to her feet. CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS. Steve stands in the b.g. She looks out at the river.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ANOTHER ANGLE to include wagon in river. Clay, suddenly furious, points to the wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the last straw. Mary turns her back, digs into her stocking and pulls out some bills. She hands them to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay looks at Mary, then down at the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and sees Steve standing scowling at him. He takes the rest of his anger out on Steve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clay strides over to his horse and swings into the saddle. Steve stands looking at Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he plunges his horse into the stream:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RIVER FULL SHOT - the lower ford. Where the main road crosses the river, it flows gently, with sand banks on either side. Three horsemen appear around a bend in the trail and ride down to the riverbank. They are Lednov, McCall and Peters. Lednov's horse is limping badly. They ride into the river.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mary --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (anxiously) Are you all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sharp) No, I'm not all right. I'm soaked and I hit myself against that rock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nettlod at her tone) I suppose that's my fault.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wailing) All my clothes -- CLAY That's right -- worry about your clothes --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about my wagon. Of all the crazy fool things to do. You lose a man's wagon because you're stupid and then yell about your clothes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For the wagon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, take it. Then you can't spend the rest of the trip expecting to get paid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (furious) There won't be any rest of the trip. Over the hill is a stage road and when we hit it you get dumped into the first stage that comes along. So keep your money. You'll need it for the fare. I'm fed up with you. I was fed up with you before we started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't just stand there. Go on back and get the packs on the horses. We've lost all the time we're going to because of a woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on. Didn't you hear me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The horses swim to shore and flounder up the bank, Lednov's horse last. As the horse starts up the bank Lednov sees something o.s. and reins the horse in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: FROM Lednov's ANGLE. A piece of clothing floats down the river. Lednov rides down the bank into the water. He reaches down awkwardly and gets the piece of clothing, then turns and rides back up the bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two others have turned and are watching him. He rides up to them, holding out one of Mary's undergarments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to scan the river.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We got company. Female company.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at the garment) Yeah, we sure have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: D PAST THEM - AT RIVER Mary's trunk comes floating by. The three men look at each other, then Lednov turns his horse and starts up the bank of the river. The others follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PEAKS OF THE SIERRA NEVADA MOUNTAINS EXTREME LONG SHOT. The long pine-covered approaches, and the glistening summit; the early snow covering the rocks with a thin layer of white. CAMERA PANS DOWN FROM the heights of the mountains, TO the narrow trail that winds among the trees. Clay passes, and behind him the pack-horses and the romuda. Following the remuda comes Mary. She is dressed in a pair of Steve's pants and wears one of his shirts under her own coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary, as she swings with the movement of the horse. She is tired. She wears no makeup. But she looks as unaffectedly beautiful as we have ever seen her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT the trail. It turns steeply, doubling back, and new Clay is directly above her. He looks down at her, but she disregards his glance. We feel that he might speak, but her cold restraint prevents him. The wind whistles through the trees. The slow plodding noise of the horses becomes more distant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . UPPER FORD - NIGHT - MOONLIGHT MED. FULL SHOT. Lednov, McCall and Peters ride slowly through the brush to where the trail enters the river. Downstream, wedged in the rocks is the wagon. The three men look at the wagon, then turn to look back along the trail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: their ANGLE. Fowler's campfire flickers through the trees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE the three men. They look at each other. Lednov motions in the direction of Fowler's camp. They start back along the trail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The three men ride along the trail toward the camp. Through the trees the campfire flickers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Fowler is putting the supper dishes up on the shelves beside the fireplace. The camp is cleaner than it was earlier in the day.
